langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Eight persons maye easely play this Commody.

1. Polliticke Perswasion the Uice. the Epiloge. for one. 2. Preface. Marquis. for another. 3. Fidence. Indigence. The second Paidge or Seruing man, The sonne of Grissill for another. 4. Reason. Diligence. Countis Mayd. Pacience. and the Daughter of Grissill for another. 5. Sobrietie. Countis of Pango. Comon people. Constancy. 6. Rumor. Iannickle. 7. Iannickells Wife. The first of the Pages. The Nursse. 8. Grissill The Midwife.

sp.l: If case by Poets skill, or Pallas prudent aid
Historians oft in Histories, their hole delights have staid
to pen and paint forth painfully, the modest lives of those,
that do in Virtues School their hope, and confidence repose:
Then wandering in the Forests wide, where fragrant flowers grow
I mean in searching Histories, wherein doth wisdom flow.
our Author found out one, wherein he took delight,
And moved thereto by his friend, gave frank consent to wright:
so simply as he could, though wanting haughty skill,
in that from Helicons fair spring, the Muses him exile:
Ne would Kay Citheria seem, Dame Clio to permit,
to garnish him with Rhetoric, the Gods did frown at it:
so peevish Pan possessed him, whose rustic Pipes did carp,
Whose concords were far dissonant, to sweet Appollois Harp:
Yet bear with him, and us also, we humbly you desire,
Let Grissills Patience swaye in you, we do you all require,
Whose History we unto you, in humble wise present,
Beseeching God, we always may in trouble be content:
And learn with her in weal and woe, the Lord our God to praise,
My time is past, my charge is done, I needs must go my ways.
Sante good Lord where am I now,
Marry I may say to you I had a sodden fall,
even now I saw Venus milking a Cow,
who toke me by the hand and led me to her palace royal
Where Cupid her son sat with his bow in hand,
like a manly Archer his foes to with stand,
She spread the table and made me good cheer,
we had Cakes and Cream plentiful store,
But thence I was taken and carried by the ear ,
And placed at the entry of Iupiters door,
who peeping out at the keyhole espied my face,
And with cap and knee welcomed my good grace,
Lord what solace was made at my entrance,
Orpheus the God of harmony, was sent for to supper,
And Mercurius for a present, a friend of mine old acquaintance,
Brought to welcome me, a dish of Almond Butter,
Saint Peter fried Pancakes a jolly good pace
And sent them as dainties to Iupiters grace
there was no remedy but I must lodge there all night,
And in the morning after breakfast was done,
I was set on a Horse which to my Judgment and sight,
Was snouted like a woodcock, and bellied like a Tonne,
But Lord so he pranced from the top of Iunos Tower,
he carried me three hundredth mile in the space of an hour,
But by chance coming to the pavilion of mighty Mars
Bellona the goddess of battle in Armour was clad,
With twenty thousand men waiting at her arse,
which sight so amazed me that as one bestraught or mad
I spurred cut with my fury outrageous and fell,
that he cast me headlong to the Dungeon of Hell,
As a new come guest I was placed at Belzabubs Table,
But such a sight of Crabtree faced knaves were servitors there ,
I swear by mine honour, I use not to fable,
They put my manly heart in a wonderful fear.
But then calling to Iupiter for his favour and grace,
I was suddenly transported, by his Angel from that place:
And set on my Horse back even as I was before,
And posting to and fro, my prancer fell on his knees:
even right against the entry, of his glorious goodly door,
who sat by the fires side, eating of Bread and Cheese:
God speed quoth I and quickly open the gate,
But he gaped greedily and bad me cease my prate,
Thou wilt wake God all mighty and his Angels out of their slumber
Nay quoth I thou art loath thy dinner to lose,
But at that word I swear by saint Duncomber
He cast me down churlish, and had like to broke my nose,
Through the thick clouds I had a marvelous fall,
that I had like to broke my neck on the top of westminster hall
But charing cross was my friend and caught my leg in his hand
The weathercock of Paules to aid me to his flight,
And between these two franions ye shall understand,
I was set on my legs and reared upright,
The cross in cheap for joy I had scaped this ill favoured chance,
Did play on a bagpipe, and the standard did dance.

body.stage: Heare let ther be aclamor, with whouping and halowinge, As thoughe ye weare huntinge, or chasinge the game.
Enter Gautir, Sansper Fidence, Reasone and Sobriete

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: even now from haughty woods, where Eccose silver sound,
Among the shrubs and valleys lo, to skies doth forth rebound
even since Aurora gan to shoe, on earth fair Phebus race,
Diana's knights by earnest toil, have followed the chase,
The wandering Buck by staggering struck, of launch from bloody bow
And nimble course of silly hounds, hath caught the over throe,
to noble states the Venal game, of hunting doth pertain,
to recreate their tristy minds, and make them joy again,
so we which long in secret close, have kept the walled town,
Did judge it mete the chase to sue, thereby to win renown,
A worthy wight I Gautier am, and Marquis by dissent,
Of parents noble sanguine race, whose fames most excellent,
in auriat trump, with cheerful voice, through Europe blown hath been
Whose just deserts in martial feats, the laurel wreath did win.
As they did safely rule, Salutias worthy town,
so I their seed do Fame achieve, who thundereth my renown:
speak on my knightly knights, each one show forth your mind
If that in us through ruling state, once faulty ye us find.

sp.speaker: Fidence.
sp.l: As you most worthy wight conserve, our country men from pain,
And seek Salutiais laws by toil, and study to maintain,
so we your liege men still consent, your honour to obeye,
Insufficient are we noble Lord, thy vertues to display:

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Hunters quoth you? marry here is a goodly rabble,
They have slain Bucks as many as I will hold in my hand,
to eat Venison the knaves be able,
But the flesh that they kill, feeds in the Sea sand:
God speed master Hunter, have you killed any Chucks,
I believe your Hounds have spoiled my Beldams Ducks.

sp.speaker: Gautier
sp.l: What art thou that thus unreverently dost prate,
Either for what cause dost thou thyself thus misuse,
Dost thou not blush my honourable estate,
Thus shamelessly with scornings to abuse.

sp.speaker: Politick.
sp.l: First to re-answer your former assertion,
what am I nay staye there, I know not myself ,
But you may see by my natural condition,
I am neither Cosset, Calf, Ox, nor Elf,
Neither the qualities of any brute beast can I put in ure,
Having such a thing a midst my face I am sure.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Thou seemest some merry companion to be,
What is thy name declare unto me.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: My name, body o God, I am clean nipped in the head,
My name, why where is it, what is it fled,
A name quoth you? marry I am now dressed in my kind,
I had rather than forty pence my name I could find:

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: Hearest thou fellow, what shall we call thee,

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: even as you please, so let it be:

sp.speaker: Sobrietie
sp.l: even as I please, I perceive thou dost dote,

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: in faith sir my name is gone to hunt Haddocks, in cock Lorells Boat,
But I will not cease hunting, as a Hound doth for his prey,
Till I have found it again by this good day,
so, so, so, lo, now seek all about,
now search every hole, within and without,
Well sought and now found at the last,
I have followed my chase wonderful fast,
Would you know my name sir shoe me with speed,
I am called Politic persuasion in deed.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Politic persuasion a name right excellent,
And for our person very convenient,
Wherefore if thou wilt with us have residence,
Thou shalt be entertained, using thy diligence,

sp.speaker: Politick.
sp.l: I thank you, and I will so do, that my behaviour,
Shall merit I trust your love and favour.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Well now my servants since ye elevate my praise,
for empery and rule what other occasion,
Resteth, that should not augment our fame always
Expressly to shoe it straight make invasion.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: None that we know, but one thing we desire,
Trusting in God that our reasonable petition,
which of your honour we crave with hearts entire,
shall be fulfilled hearing thereof definition.

sp.speaker: Gautier
sp.l: Say what you please we do you freely license,
I cannot grant before I hear your sentence.

sp.speaker: Fidence.
sp.l: Long time have we your servants hard, the; commons muttering voice
Long time have we concealed the cause, why they cannot rejoice
Long time have we in secret close, gushed forth our bitter tears
Long have we spent in doleful plaints, these fragrant fertile years
The cause unknown to you we Judge, of this our mestful cheer
which to redress prepare with speed, to hear thy listening ear.

sp.speaker: Politicke Per.
sp.l: for twenty pound here is some broil toward,
Now Politic persuasion shoe forth thy skill,
I will make him obstinate stubborn and froward,
If that I may achieve my purpose and will.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Why friends what thing should move you thus, in secret to complain
Why should you keep from me the thing, that doth augment your pain,
Of nature am I such a one, that rigours force do use,
to give regard to your complaints, did I as yet refuse,
Then why from me should ye thus hide, the thing that causeth grief
speak on faint not, ostend your woe, doubt not to find relief.

sp.speaker: Politicke Per.
sp.l: Honestly spoken I swear by Saint tan,
My master you see is a frank hearted Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Reasone
sp.l: we cannot cease but justly yield, to thee condignly praise,
which gratefully re-answerest us, the Lord prolong thy days,
And grant thee double Nestors years, tranquillity and peace,
that thou mayst rule and safely reign, with honours just increase.

sp.speaker: Politicke Per.
sp.l: This is a goodly kind of salutation, and a wonderful kind of regratulation
I am plain Dunstable I may say to you,
I am as homely as the good wife that for love kissed her Cow.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie
sp.l: This is the mean why we remain, in pensive pained plight,
This is the cause that anguish doth, our solace banish quit,
that you in single state abide, and marriage do refrain
would god you would enjoy that yoke, then assuaged were our pain
Then should our mestful hearts that long, have subject been to woe
Cast off the clog of heaviness, and dreary tears forgo,
Then should our tristful minds exile, their doleful deadly care,
And joy, infringe those grisly gulfs, which doth our footsteps snare

sp.speaker: Politicke Per.
sp.l: Bones is all this entreatance for wiving,
Some men are married, and would be unwedded again ,
And some men never fall to thriving,
Before they be spoused, this is evident and plain,
But whosoever intendeth of that mystery to be taster.
Findeth oft times the gray mare better master.

sp.speaker: Gautier
sp.l: My friends full friendly I reply, with protestation due,
that single life preferred is, in sacred scripture true,
But happy are the married sort, which live in perfect love,
Twice happier are the single ones, Saint Paull doth plainly prove,
for such as lead a virgins life, and sinful lust expel,
in heaven above the ethereal skies, with Christ their lord shall dwell.

sp.speaker: Fidence.
sp.l: we grant that scripture doth extol, vestais savoury flower
And happy are the continent, which rest within her bower,
But yet for you more mete it were, conjoined for to be,
that after you your seat of rule, might have the dignity,
for where there is no issue left the wise man sayeth plain,
that every man in Lordly state, doth covet for to reign.

sp.speaker: Politicke Per.
sp.l: Baw waws is no wedding the proverb doth tell,
Marry quoth you? I hard many a one say,
that the first day for wedding all other doth excel,
for after they have had not one merry day.
Quod the good wife I would be uncoupled, and with sobs the same wished
for I shall never have health in my head, while he hath pith in his fist,
Saith the good man, I have such a shrew to my wife,
I speak unfeignedly, I swear by Gods mother,
I am half weary of this present life,
to be rid I would give the Devil one half to fetch the other:
I speak not generally, all run not this race,
But some are ready to catch their husbands by the face.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: What joy should such as subjects be, to see this day possess,

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Content your minds if case I grant, your state for to redress:
Ye shall permit your worthy Lord, in choice to use his skill,
And eke permit as reason is, to marry whom I will.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie
sp.l: Choose where you please, take who ye list, we will you not gainsay.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Then will I soon elect my mate, and time shall haste the day.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: lo now my Lord will be married, we shall have a feast,
But where is his wife, can any man tell,
He will have such a one I judge at the least,
Whose beautiful countenance, shall Hellen excel,
A fair girl, trick, and minikin trim:
A neat trull, which in years shall be like unto him,
now God of his grace, in your choice send you good luck,
And grant that your love may last forever,
I beseech God send you with her, as many horns as a Buck,
that your tongue, her nose, and my tail: may be joined together.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: God grant that in love ye may continue together.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Well now let us depart this place.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: we will wait upon you by Gods grace.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Nay I will follow after as fast as I can,
for if I be missing my Lord lacks a man.

body.stage: heare enter Grissell, Syngyng. and Spinning: wyth her Parents, and Indigent Pouertie.

sp.l: God by his providence divine,
Hath formed me of slimy Clay,
Then why should I in aught repine,
Or seek his will to disobey:
Be it far from me to do such ill,
As to contend against his will:
Singe danderly Distaff, and danderly
Ye Virgins all come learn of me.
Let Children to their parents give,
Obedience due, as they are taught,
Then they on earth full long shall live,
and joy the place which Christ hath bought
With his heart blood, and deadly wound,
Where lasting joys shall aye abound,
Singe danderly Distaff, and danderly,
Let children all come learn of me.
Though Aetas on my parents here,
by crooked shape have shown his power,
Yet I am bound to dread and fear,
Them tide and time and every hour:
for God to me hath given such charge,
As in his law is seen at large,
Sing danderly Distaff, and danderly,
Each child with speed come learn of me.
Set Natures laws before your eyes,
which may your tender minds constrain,
All crooked language to despise,
And mend your miss, for fear of pain,
The stubborn child, the Lord doth threat
in hell to chasten, with torments great,
danderly Distaff, and danderly,
Ye Virgins all come learn of me.
Conserve and keep virginity,
Your conscience do not pollute,
But walk in true integrity,
all sinful lust do clean confute,
Fly such men as, would you allure
to spot with lust your lives so pure,
danderly Distaff, and danderly,
Ye Virgins all come learn of me.
Obey such men as you do serve
Use diligence at all assays,
Then fame her Trumpet will preserve
to thunder forth to skies your praise
From filthy speech your tongues refrain,
Let godliness in you remain,
danderly distaff, and danderly,
Ye Virgins all come learn of me.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: How do you my Parents? I pray you declare:

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: Well good daughter God be praised.

sp.speaker: Ianikell
sp.l: Truly I thank God that merry ye are.

sp.speaker: Indigent.
sp.l: o how joyful would I be, if God in my age had raised,
me such a child, to comfort my needful indigence,
She never ceaseth toiling, but laboureth always,
Showing to you the fruits of true obedience:
Of her birth good neighbours be joyful ye may ,
for to your hoary heads, she is a perfect staye.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: in youthful days when sappy youth, his blossoms did display,
When every limb, for want of strength through green years had no stay
My Parents here still careful were, their child with food to nourish,
As duty was so Nature wrought, they did me ever cherish,
From tender days to this estate, by pain they have me brought,
And now that age hath clogged them both, to comfort them I ought
But yet my pain unable is, their pains to recompense:
Whose studies still employed were, to save from inconvenience,
Their only child they fostered aught, with sustenance full due,
And should I now ungratefully, with vile disdain pursue
no God forbid , that through my fault, I should their grief's increase
to labour still to comfort them, these hands shall never cease

sp.speaker: Ianicle.
sp.l: Ah my dear Child whose flouring youth, in virtue still doth flourish
our hoary heads if thou wert not, for food were like to perish,
our backs were like for want of cloth, extreme cold to abide,
But thou for us continually, by labour dost provide,
Thy diligence my neighbours all, can justly further port,
Thou art thy parents only staye, and staff of their comfort.

sp.speaker: Mater.
sp.l: Grissill I pray thee to my talk give good head,
Thou seest thy father is lame and I very old,
Cease not as thou hast begun to comfort his need,
for the pangs of death on me have taken hold,
I feel myself very sick, increased is my pain,
Naught now but the ground can make me fain.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Good mother comfort yourself be of good cheer,
You shall want nothing your pains to assuage,
Let not sickness cause you anything to fear,
for that may be a mean to enlarge your damage.

sp.speaker: Mater.
sp.l: dear Child of thy wonted care and diligence,
Thy father and I have perfect intelligence,
Whose age see thou hold in worthy estimation,
love and obey him give him, due veneration,
Then God will bless thee with his spirit and grace,
Yea on earth thou shalt long run thy race,
Be not high minded, let not Pride infect thee ,
Lest God in his wrath with his scourge correct thee ,
Be no pickthank, seek not the fruits of dissension,
Be rather a peace maker to banish contention,
Be sloe to speak let thy words be witty,
for, for a Damsel to have many words it is unfit,
Let love and obedience in thy heart be fully placed,
Let contumelious disdain be utterly defaced
Grudge not in aught against thy fathers will,
But be always ready his mind to fulfil,
And show thyself of a godly behaviour,
that of God and man thou mayst merit the favour.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Mother all that you have said shall observed be.

sp.speaker: Ianickel.
sp.l: o my dear wife how is it with thee .

sp.speaker: Mater.
sp.l: even as it pleaseth God good husband Ianakell
But flesh and blood is very frail and brittle,
for such was the cause wherefore mankind was framed.
But hope is my staff which fleshly affection hath tamed,
Where with through Christ my only justification,
I strive against sin, death and, damnation,
And even amidst the bitter pangs of death,
Whose gripes most sharp seemed to close my breath,
I appeal to Christ for mercy and grace,
Trusting among his saints in the heavens to have place.

sp.speaker: Ianickel
sp.l: Alas poor man in creased is thy pain,
Just cause hast thou to languish and complain.

sp.speaker: In.pouert
sp.l: Good neighbour I am heartily sorry for your sickness,
But comfort yourself brother Ianickell let go your heaviness.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Come on dear mother stay on my shoulder let us depart this place,
You shall want nothing to comfort you with all.

sp.speaker: Mother.
sp.l: I know that thou wilt respect my case,
How be it I am glad that death to me is befall,
for now shall I as a pilgrim from pilgrims travel be free,
And through Christ enjoy heavenly felicity.

sp.speaker: Ianickle
sp.l: Well being fully furnished with anguish and pain,
I will to my cottage to comfort my wife this is plain.

sp.speaker: Indigent
sp.l: And I will bear you company with all festination,
Doing all I may to turn to joy your lamentation.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Aye marry now all is as it should be , Gods ye God morrow game,
I trow ye will say that well nurtured I am.
But yonder is such tidings as will make you glad,
The Marquis for Marriage I trow will run mad,
for all his mind I tell you with out any let,
to praise his spouse I promise you is set,
Ye shall hear anon how he will lift her up to skies,
As though there were none more witty virtuous or wise,
I cannot blame him though he commend his own,
But to none of his court the gentlewoman is known ,
And therefore to wonder their minds I incense,
so that every man longeth to view the Ladies presence.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: o so this heart doth long, to spread my Ladies fame,
And yet my tongue unable is, to laud that worthy dame,
for beauty I to Hellin may, aptly the maid compare,
Such vertues in a younglings breast, is seldom seen or rare,
A Phillis for her constant truth, a Thisbe for her love,
her arguments most pithy do, her vertues daily prove.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: for beauty quoth you, is she so amiable to the eye,
Are her vertues superabundant that they can not be told
I say no more tracked of time the thing shall try.
I think such a wife would very well be sold,
You may coarse her if it like you, and perhaps catch a worse,
The pride of some dames make the husband bear an empty purse
They must be trimmed after the trickiest fashion,
Fine waters must be bought for beauties preservation,
There hair with a bodkin must be curled after the finest guise,
their Neats tongues with peaks must hang over their eyes,
And to make them seem proper heated, fine caps they have,
Such as will scantily cover the crown, I think as God me save,
But to make them sit clean I swear by Saint tan,
They cut of off their hair, as I am an honest man,
Somebody can tell that I use not to lie,
And I warrant you ye shall some of these tricks in her espy,

sp.speaker: Fidence.
sp.l: Truth such pride in the world is now resident,
As in no time the like hath been seen with eye,

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: Many men and women I judge are impudent,
for pride they embrace with minds full greedy.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie
sp.l: As God for pride did plague Sodome and Gomora in his ire.
so will he destroy the wicked with flaming fire.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: I know that pride embraced is, and some their state exceed,
But my elected mate God knows, with vice will not proceed,
She will observe a modest mean, her vertues shall increase,
All hateful hate in her shall end, she loveth perfect peace,
She feareth God, she dreads his name, she leads a Godly life,
And daily seeks for to subdue, contention and strife,
She will as duty binds, her spoused mate obeye,
From husbands hests at no time she for any cause will straye.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: If she be so holy a saint as you make her ,
Refuse her I beseech you and I myself will take her ,
Such a Marriage would I have, if I should choose,
Then should I be sure she would me not misuse,
I might say what I would, and do what I list,
he that hath such a wife of God he is blissed,
But most wives are so knappish and cutted now,
that they will be known to bear rule I say to you,
Rule quoth I, yea and more than reason doth require,
Yea and especially after that to mastership they aspire,
Then huff all ahoy their tongues must be taunting,
The flag in the top mast, must needs be flaunting,
And now and then I swear by all hallows,
The nobsis be so nice that they will eat no mallows,
so coy are the mincing muses, that drink of bellonas well,
that oft times they conquer their husbands in battle,
Yea and now and then I swear by this light,
Betwixt them on her part is proclaimed open fight,
God send the gray mare good footing and to amble apace,
for now and then her ten commandments are seen in the goodman's face

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: This talk from a mind malicious doth proceed,
therefore cease this vain clatter,

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: I tell you plain that some wives resemble the cockatrice in dead.
I speak plainly I cannot flatter,
think not that envy doth give me occasion,
no their natures be known to Politic persuasion,
Try them who will shall my words true find,
Some of them I tell you will be stubborn and unkind,
Deny them of their wills and then ye mar all,
Ye shall see what there after is like for to fall,
Either brawling, jawling, snapping, or snarling,
their tongues shall not cease but always be jarring,
Or else they will counterfeit a kind of hypocrisy,
And simper like a fermenting pot, the finger shall be in their eye
they will say, love is forgotten though my love be shown,
I see you love another better than your own,
Tush, tush, I know full well their meaning and intent
They be the craftiest cattle in Christendom or kent.

sp.speaker: Fidence.
sp.l: Well set all these words a part dear friend,
Though some be froward all do not to frowardness condescend,
for I of Marriage know the just probation,
And doubtless my wife leadeth an honest conversation.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Yea but some times you give her, Her own will.

sp.speaker: Fidence.
sp.l: Yea and reason.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Or else I warrant you your ears with brawlings she would fill,
If the good wife should not some times bear all the stroke,
Throughout the house she would raise such a smoke,
that either bitterly her tongue should run at large,
Or else should her eyes fountains of tears discharge,
Tush whole bushels of tears fall from their eyes,
The syrup were notable to savour wardon pies,
But if self will were bridled, then men should live at rest,
With womanly actions they should not be oppressed.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: My subjects now whose long desire, doth wish my Marriage day
Shall have the thing that they expect, with out longer delay,
Wherefore my knights yourselves bedeck, in sumptuous array,
to solemnise with out all let, this long desired day,

sp.speaker: Sobrietie
sp.l: o noble Lord with willing mind we grant to do the same.

sp.speaker: Reason.
sp.l: we will apparel ourselves, with all the world shall speak of your fame

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: tomorrow next I will fetch home my spouse,

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: by my troth if it like your honour she is a handsome blowze.
Gyll sparrow that milked good man peatches Cows,

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: I said I would fetch home my Lady with celerity,

sp.speaker: Sobrietie.
sp.l: And I will wait on you this is the verity,

sp.speaker: Fidence.
sp.l: I will go with you as duty doth me bind,

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: And I of your company will be glad,
And if I can ever an old blanket find,
I hope for my part to be handsomely clad,

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: What sayst thou.

sp.speaker: Politick.
sp.l: I say after diner a banquet shall be assigned,
Notable fair in your Hall shall be had.

sp.speaker: Gautier
sp.l: Come on let us depart with speediness.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: to do as you will us we be in a readiness.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Nay fare ye well God be your speed,
I tell you I come after as fast as I can,
I am a goodly fellow to help at a need,
Nay by mine honour I am a handsome serving man,
Well I will go post to fetch home his wife,
Whose vertues as he saith are wonderful rife,
God dyld ye, God thank ye, for my friendly company,
I must needs be packing I swear by Saint Antonye,
Fare ye well, God be with you, gentle friends adieu,
I am the properest fellow that ever man knew.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Ah Grissell now mayst thou complain, (infortune thine alas)
thy tender days in deadly dole, thou now must learn to pass,
for, thou hast lost a Jewel great, whose like is rare to find,
Whose want to wail, unto thine eyes, a flood of tears is sent:
Thou now art motherless become, the grave her lodge doth rest,
Whose death to mourn with sobbing shrieks, and sighs, you now art pressed
Was never child had greater loss, nor cause of carking care,
Help me to weep all such (alas) that careful Children are:
for I alack do miss my joy, and best instructors found,
I rest alive? but she by death, lieth closed fast in ground.
Wherefore ye Muses nine: that on Pernasso rest,
Caleiope, Thersicora and Clio do your best:
Strain forth your notes of wailful woes, weep you and mourn with me:
that Gods and men, my inward grief, apparent now may see.
sp.stage: Here Grissell Singith a songe, to the tune of Damon & Pithias.
sp.l: Can my poor heart be still,
can I possess sweet peace:
When Ioue hath given Parchas the charge,
my blissful joys to cease:
Judge you my cause, you tender youths
that gained your mothers love,
And you shall find to mourn and weep
Dame Nature doth me move:
My mother was my bliss,
her sight did banish care:
But now to weep and mourn alack,
her absence I prepare:
I miss her counsels sweet to me,
thrice blissed happy Dame:
who trained me up in Virtues school,
that I may purchase Fame.
And when that Atropos
came stealing on apace,
to see how she in tender arms
her Grissell did embrace:
My tears like Fountains rushed out,
to show my grief and pain:
Whose want to wail in woeful wise
Nature doth me constrain.
But she the heavens hath won,
and with the Saints doth reign,
in endless bliss where Christ our Lamb,
doth her revive again,
And I am left behind to live,
with my sweet father dear,
to whom whilst life shall reign in me,
obeisance I will bear.

sp.speaker: i.
sp.l: A sirrah my master is gone to my Lord Marquis place,
And I by his side have posted a pace,

sp.speaker: ii.
sp.l: And so have I by mine, I swear by Gods mother,
I warrant thee I sweat so that every drop over taketh other,

sp.speaker: i.
sp.l: Gog's wounds let me see, sure here is a mad smell,
All the place savoureth of thy knaves grease I see well,

sp.speaker: ii.
sp.l: Gog's blood knave, art thou knowing by kind,
A greasier knave than thyself, a man cannot find

sp.speaker: i.
sp.l: Cry you mercy gentleman, can ye bide no board
I will clap ye about the costard with the hilts of my sword,
Art thou knowing of me, hence dizzardly fool,

sp.speaker: ii.
sp.l: Guts I have seen as wise a man as you, wear a hood and a collar,

sp.speaker: i.
sp.l: Am I a fool, gog's heart Iacke sauce I shake you by the ears,
Go prate with thine equals you whoreson foolish boy,

sp.speaker: ii.
sp.l: Gog's flesh, hears more a do with Iacke Napes, the twenty Bears,
Alas goodman man you need not be so coy,

sp.speaker: i.
sp.l: Blood shall I be flouted of a baggage boy, I rid thee hold thy prate
But for wearing my masters patapls I would beat thee about thy pat

sp.speaker: ii.
sp.l: About my pate not a rush for thee I do not care,
Spare not me mast man but do what you dare,

sp.speaker: i.
sp.l: Then I will bob you you patch, for your mocks,

sp.speaker: ii.
sp.l: Be well assured thou shalt bear me some knocks.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Now that my spinning ended is, and house full cleanly made,
to void the gulfs of Idleness, and use some honest trade
to well spring where the crystal streams, of waters still increase
With prone and ready willing mind, to go I may not cease,
for I will fetch from thence with speed, some wholelsome water sweet
And dainty broth for parent make, as fitly is and meet,
It is the duty of a child, her fathers age to love,
to nourish him as he did me, it doth me now behove,
in arms full oft he lulled me, and food me often gave ,
Then why should I in any jot, of duty him deprave,
for God full straightly hath given charge, to honour him a right,
which precept I will aye observe, to utmost of my might,
And hastily from Well return, to comfort him with food,
Warm meats are meet for aged folk, to nourish up their blood.
Come on with me ye worthy wights, which aye deserve renown,
Ye Nobles all which aye rested, within Salutias town,
Most gratefully I yield you thanks, for this your taken pain,
If God permit to length my life, I will requite again,
Your friendly hearts with friendliness, since friendship's fruits ye shoe
The fulness of the same in time, on you I will bestow.

sp.speaker: Reason.
sp.l: As duty binds so love constrains, us on you to attend,
Your honours gentle nature doth, such love to us extend,
that love inflames our gentle hearts, to honour you aright,
And to advance thy hie estate, to utmost of our might.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie
sp.l: Condignly we to thee O Lord, our offered service give,
Beseeching Ioue that sittest above , the heavens, you long may live
in prosperous state to comfort ours, then shall our joy increase ,
And eke Salutias love shall reap, through you the fruits of peace.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: I give you thanks assuredly, from depth of secret heart.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Ye matrons all ye Ladies fair, like thanks I do impart,
to you whose pregnant minds, such clemency bestow,
As doth belong to gentle hearts, like friendliness to show:
Wherefore Nature doth urge me still, to show your worthy praise,
Shown largely to me youthful wight, in these my tender days.
which thus much have respected me, to deck with rich renown
Your governor and only Lord, which rules Salutias town,
I mean in that ye ready are, attendance due to give,
And to fetch home my mate elect, with whom in love I live.

sp.speaker: Ladies
sp.l: No more but duty we do show, wherefore your mind content,
to honour you with reverence due, we Ladies all be bent.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: now that my Pot to brinks I have filled,
I will haste me home with all convenient speed:
God grant I may do as my mother me willed,
Then God will prosper me in time of need,
Let all Children be mindful of obedience in deed:
Fly self-will, which doth stubbornness engender,
to honour your Parents do daily remember:
Be they never so poor or indigent,
If God have blessed thee with store and increase,
Remember the paps of thy mother gave thee nourishment,
to feed and cloth thee, their care did never cease,
Relieve and comfort them , so end thy days in peace,
If not look for Gods scourge and cursed malediction:
which shall fall upon thee, for thy stubborn infection,
Well I will home with my water Pot without delay,
I would be loath to offend my father with long tarriance,
for such as provoke their friends to ire day by day,
Cannot escape Gods terrible vengeance.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: God speed Damsel, soft whether away,

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Truly my Lord homeward, as fast as I may .

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Where is your father, express to me with speed.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: in his poor Cottage he resteth in deed.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Haste and tell him with all festination,
that with him his Lord will have communication.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Your commandment with speed performed shall be,
I will return quickly, your honour shall see,
Good Father be not offended with me I you desire,
Because so long from you I have been absent.

sp.speaker: Ianickel.
sp.l: Ah daughter Grissell, why shouldest thou such a thing require,
Thou art returned very soon in my judgment.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Not so good Father, for coming by the way,
I had an occasion and was forced to staye:
My Lord Gauter our governor excellent,
Whom courteously I saluted, with words reverent:
Willed me to haste home to my habitation,
who stayeth hereby, with you to have communication:
Wherefore good father without longer delay,
Let us repair to his presence as fast as we may.

sp.speaker: Ianickel
sp.l: O dear Child I will haste to him with diligence.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: God grant he may relieve our indigence.

sp.speaker: Ianickle
sp.l: o honourable lord, God send thee felicity,
Thy hoar headed subject, thy person doth reverence:
Right worthy Lords God bless you with prosperity,
And shield you fair Ladies from all inconvenience.

sp.speaker: Gauter.
sp.l: o Ianicle we thee re-greet, again in friendly wise,
that God protect both thee and thine, that sits in ethereal skies:
Incline thy aged ears to me, my loquie well perpend,
Hark, mark and give regard, to that I shall ostend:
Requite my friendly heart, and gratify again,
Thy Lord which for thy Daughter here doth suffer extreme pain
who knoweth the panges of love, or feels her passions dire,
What living wight more than my self, abideth Cupids ire,
Such is the force of ardent fire, that boils in secret breast
so severe is the darted wound, with which I am oppressed,
that my poor blading heart doth faint, and comfort none can find,
Except that you do grant a salve, to ease my doleful mind.

sp.speaker: Ianakell
sp.l: O God who would have thought, that such a noble heart,
Would have been set on flaming fire, by blinded Cupids dart,
Assuage your filthy lust, fly Uenus wanton ways,
O mortify your appetite, do naught regard her plays,
Abhor her careless court, her muster Books eschew,
so shall you quench that flaming fire, which gives you cause to rue
so shall you staunch the wound, wherewith your heart is pained,
so shall no spark of grief be left, but perfect health be gained.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Know that I mind not to pollute, the chaste virginity,
But rather seek the loss of life, to keep integrity,
I am not Uenus darling I, her court I do not use,
to be enrolled in her Books, my senses all refuse,
her bestial plays I hate, her pleasures filthy are,
Disloyal lust cannot attempt, to trap me in his snare,
But from profounded heart, doth perfect love proceed,
Now condescend to save or spill, grant mercy to my meed.

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: If case your love be faithful pure, your love deserveth praise.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Right sovereign Lord, respect your young and tender days,
Your Noble state your dignity, your honour and your name,
Your worthy birth your parents race, achieving trump of fame
And eke lift up thine eyes, my poor degree behold,
My poor estate my misery, the time doth forth unfold,
What better proof can be here of, than these our rags so torn,
These paint and shoe our penury, which we to bide were borne,
These things full duly weighed, in balance equal right,
May alter and infringe thy mind, and purposed delight,
for they may blemish quit, thy stock and worthy race,
Thy honour and thy ancestors, at once they do deface,
therefore go choose a better choice, elect a meeter mate,
which may increase and ample make, thy worthy sanguine state.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: o Grissill thee I love, now length or short my life,
Let pity now appear to be, within thy breast full rife,
It shall no whit abase my state, nor minish my renown,
But cause thy fame thundered forth, through out our royal town
What shall each wight report of thee , if rigour thou now use,
If my untimely death thou haste, canst thou thyself excuse?
A murderess thou shalt termed be, all men shall thee disdain,
which cruelly without desert, thy only Lord hast slain,
An Iphis I whose kindly heart, doth beg and crave thy grace,
If thou Anaxaretis be, and turn from me thy face,
Poor Teucers son is then forlorn , the Troyan is undone,
If Iphis I do play my part, contempt thou canst not shun,
Thy poverty can naught prevail, thy rigour to obscure,
But rather cause and stir each wight, disdain to put in ure
Thy ragged clothes the argue not, in poor estate to live,
Thy vertues noble do thee make, such Fate doth Fortune give,
that thou above all virgins art, by trump of Fame extolled,
give rightful Doom to Pyramus, like Thisbe love unfold.

sp.speaker: Ianickel.
sp.l: My Daughter is a Virgin pure, and wanteth terrene store.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: for that respect doth faithful love, in me increase the more.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Much musing in my mind, in this sort I reply,
Why should you seem me wretched wight, to love thus faithfully
I neither have fair Helins shape, nor comely shining hew,
Ne yet no kind of earthy coin, ne substance this is true,
And as for costly ornaments, and sumptuous array,
I want, the best even now on me behold you may ,
there rests within this noble Town, full many a worthy dame,
which both for store and feature fair, deserves the voice of Fame:
They may you hie renown augment, and elevate to skies,
Take one of them, my low estate and Parents stock despise:
Let Grissell with her father live, bestow on them your love,
This answer take? with equal state learn now your suit to prove:
be Iphis true to such a one, as plenty hath and store,
Choose like to like leave off for shame, express thy suit no more.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: o careless youth that naught regardest, my plaints and doleful tears
o direful day, o hapless hap, o shortener of my years:
o pray appointed for my death, which lightly dost regard
The life of him, which thou with love shouldst gratefully reward:
Asunder break thou heart, which thus with grief art tossed,
Yield up thy breath from Prison free, thy poor tormented ghost:
why shouldst thou longer live, to couch on heaps thy pain:
I loath my life, since my good will doth reap my self disdain,
If ever ruth did rest, within your rueful hearts,
Stream forth your plaints ye Muses all, with tears bewail my smarts:
Take Wellspring's to your eyes, let doleful tunes abound,
o pearce and fill the haughty clouds, with your lamenting sound:
Show forth my faithful heart, be records of my love,
These plaints thrown forth, my constancy apparently do prove,
o Ianickle whose age, ought honoured to be,
If case that Nature in the rest, I pray thee pity me.

sp.speaker: Ianickle
sp.l: If that these tears streamed forth, from depth of heart proceed,
And I shall grant to give thee grace, to recompense thy meed:
Plight faith and troth to me: thou wilt not her deflower,
Ne spoil her Garden fragrant, of Uirins fruitful flower.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: to record Heaven I call, and God that lives therein:
Plighting my faith in open press, to shun such filthy sin,
I mind not as a Harlot I, with her to lead my life,
But by the force of wedlocks knot, to take her as my wife.

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: Then to your honour I, my daughter dear do give:
Beseeching God that in his fear, together you may live.

sp.speaker: Gautier
sp.l: o happy be thy aged life, and fortunate I pray,
which hast preserved thy loving Lord, from danger and decay:
Welcome to me my mate elect, my joy and hearts delight,
The perfect length of vital life, which grief extirpest quite.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Since it hath pleased you loving Lord, to fix your love on me,
Faith, love, and obedience due, I yield here unto thee.

sp.speaker: Gauter.
sp.l: These gifts more precious are than Gold,
And far excel all terrene treasure:
o it delighteth me much thee to behold,
in thy presence consisteth my solace and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: (Alas) poor silly girl increased is thy smart,
From father now in aged days, perforce thou must depart,
who now in time of need, shall thy estate relieve?
to leave thee destitute of help, thy daughter sore doth grieve,
who now shall roll thy back, and daily give thee food:
I know not one that readily, will do my father good,
If that thou pine, I pine like case, I die if aught thou want,
to wend from thee thus suddenly, my dolours are not scant,
who now shall comb thy hoary beard, who now shall wash thy head
who now to ease thy aged bones, shall beat and make thy Bed.

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: Comfort thyself my child, for me God will provide,
he is my Rock, my staff, my stay, my trust and perfect guide,
And since that he by providence, respected hath thy state,
And to the top of Fortunes wheel, in mercy elevate,
Lament no more, distill no tears, though thou depart me from,
for God that rules both heaven and earth, hath willed it should be so:
Swell not in Pride still gentile be, and lead a lowly mind,
to all estates full courteous be, as Nature hath assigned.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: I will observe your hests, to utmost of my might.

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: Then God will bless thee with his grace and sprite.

sp.speaker: Gauter.
sp.l: My Ladies all I you require, my comely spouse array,
that we may haste to solemnise, our happy wedding day,
These ornaments receive, to deck her corpse with all.

sp.speaker: Ladies
sp.l: Right worthy Lord in every point, fulfil your mind we shall:
Come Lady mine to fathers house lead us the ready way.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: I yield ye matrons to your hest, come on with me I pray.

sp.speaker: Ianickel
sp.l: Right honourable Lord give thy servant licence,
to show my mind at large unto thee.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Good father show forth the fulness of thy sentence,
Without longer let I heartily pray thee.

sp.speaker: Ianickel
sp.l: If God pourforth on you the Oil of his Unction,
And with fertility thy Vineyard increase,
I mean if he add his spiritual benediction,
And give you children bring them up in his peace,
Instruct them to fear God, and their Parents to obeye:
Then God will preserve them from ruinous decay,
Keep them always under lawful correction:
Restrain in them, swearing, and all ungodliness,
Chastise and punish them, lest sinful infection,
Allure them to all mischief and wickedness,
so shall God prosper you with his spirit and grace,
And they as he hath promised, shall on earth long run their race:
love one another, the seeds of Enmity eschew,
for whereas faithful love is remanent,
There Hatred is subdued, this is most true:
And Gods fear is evermore with such couples resident,
But whereas is the contrary, I mean strife and Variance:
There the Devil is head, and hath the hole governance.

sp.speaker: Gautier
sp.l: Father think not that oblivion shall be frequented,
God willing all that you have said shall be attempted:
for where Children are not punished for their sin,
There mischief to spring doth fully begin:
There Oaths abound, there Lies most odious,
Begin to take root, as hurtful and pernicious:
If Nature be corrupted with poisoned infection,
Then resteth there Gods curse and heavy malediction,
therefore in tender years, while youth is green and fresh,
All lewd enormities a Rod may redress:
Lest further inconvenience, in age happen to grow,
As is seen of such as wickedness do follow.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: in deed a man may bow a Twig which way he list,
so in Infancy a Child with good manners furnished,
in age in Virtue will willingly persist,
And such a one of God is surely blissed.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie.
sp.l: Children chastised in Infancy, in age fly sin,
But if Parents cloak their godless conversation,
in the end to contemn their superiors they begin,
Therefore correction bringeth them to good education.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: Low noble Lord have we long been absent.

sp.speaker: Gauter
sp.l: no truly and therefore I am the better content.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: O noble Lord, these costly Robes, unfitly seem to be:
My ragged weed much more than this, doubtless contented me.

sp.speaker: Gauter
sp.l: These garments now to thine estate belong, my Lady dear,
Disdain them not, but for my sake refuse them not to wear.

sp.speaker: Ianickll
sp.l: Set Gods fear before thine eyes good Grissell.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Your hest shall be observed good father Ianickel,
But my heart is much pained to depart thee from .

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: Rejoice for needly from me thou must go.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Receive this friendly kiss, so now God be thy aid.

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: Faint not for on him all my care is laid.

sp.speaker: Gauter.
sp.l: Come let us depart with all celerity,
Sound up your Instruments, be joyful Nobility?
And in token of Victory, some Song I will singe,
which to perform Lady, I must have your helping.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Begin when you please my Lord, for with a willing mind,
to help you all I may , ready ye shall me find.

body.stage: Singe and then go out. To the tune of malkin.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Since Fate and Fortune thus agree,
My only joy and Lady dear:
A Romeo I will rest to thee,
in whom the fruits of Faith appear:
Heigh hoaw, my true love,
I joy in thee my Turtle Dove.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Since heavenly Gods that rule above,
have lotted me to be your wife:
A Thisbe just thy spouse will prove,
Whilst Ioue give charge to end my life:
Heigh hoaw, my sweet heart,
I honour thee, while death us part.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Low, here thy Lord doth thee embrace,
Whose sight far dearer seems than life:
Within my breast thou gainest place,
Welcome to me most loving wife:
Heigh hoaw, my true love,
I fancy thee, my Turtle Dove.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: no Tarquins knight, ne Appian now,
Shall cause me shrink from duty due,
Penellope I will stand to you,
As Lady just and faithful true:
Heigh hoawe, my sweet heart,
I am thine own, while death do part.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Thy Virtues seem no less to be,
With Alcest fair compare you may :
Thy modest life inflamed me,
to join and knit this knot today ,
Heigh hoaw my true love,
I am thine own my Turtle Dove.
Not Cressus gold nor Midas muck,
My fancy fixed may seem to change,
Diana doth me still in struck,
to Venus knights aye to be strange,
Heigh hoaw my sweet heart,
I honour thee while death us part.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Fare well to thee good father Ianickle

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: God give your honour joy, of my daughter Grissell
The Lord be with you, and both your loves increase,
And grant you to end your days in his peace:
I cannot but wonder to see the inflammation,
Of love, which here fully hath shown her operation:
Provoking this Marquis nourished in prosperity,
to love poor Grissell tasting so much poverty,
But it is thy providence my God, that this to pass hath brought,
by thy divine wisdom this action was wrought.
God be their defence and keep them from damage:
Well I will leave musing and go to my cottage.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: now Politic Persuasion, now or else never,
Fie, for chaffing I can scant keep my teeth together ,
I tell you I have found out such an invention,
As among the common sort, shall kindle dissension:
A Marquis married to a beggarly Grissill
her father an old fool, and an impotent cripple,
His store and substance in value not worth twenty pence,
This gear cannot choose but breed inconvenience,
I will not cease privily her confusion to work,
for under Honey the proverb saith poison may lurk:
so though I simulate externally love to pretend,
My love shall turn to mischief, I warrant you in the end:
The pretty fool is puffed up , her belly is big,
I conjecture the trull will bring forth some proper Pig:

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: in public toil in countries strange, full often I have been,
where Matrons chaste and Ladies fair, these earthy eyes have seen:
But now for wisdom's obsequies, to Grissill I compare,
to say the truth her modest life, and vertues are most rare.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie
sp.l: You say the truth for only she , all men confess the same,
for courteous facts and loquie mild, deserves a worthy name.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: o so these gentlemen praise and lift her to the skies,
I could find in my heart to pluck out the beggars brats eyes:
Fie on it, it grieveth me to the very heart,
A Lady honourable, nay a Whip and a Cart:
Bones here is stuff if the world were quick,
These younkers with a vengeance, are come in the nick,
I will to them I, to put my practise in ure,
My countenance shall be grave, sad and demure.
God speed gentlemen ye are welcome hither,
Methought of Grissell I horde you common together:
Praising her for Virtues, such as be seen but rare,
to commend her so highly very much to blame ye are:
I knew her offspring I, from the beginning,
Is she any more than a Beggars brat, brought up in spinning,
her father is indigent, needy, and lame,
An old doting fool, that Ianickle hath to name:
in her there is no jot of noble sanguinity,
therefore unfitly that her seed should rule or have dignity.

sp.speaker: Reason.
sp.l: Content thy mind thy talk is vain, thou seekst to heap up strife,
I cannot choose but needs commend, her good and honest life,
above all spoused Dames, which bide within this town,
She best deserves the price of praise, and Helm of rich renown.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie.
sp.l: The Scorpion forth will fling, his poison to annoy,
And passengers that pass him by , with Venom to destroy,
so thou whose malice doth abound, thy sting dost now prepare,
to vex and harm those wights, whose lives most virtuous are.

sp.speaker: Politick.
sp.l: Not I for twenty pound, will hurt her by the Rood:
that which I have spoken is sure the verity,
If I could hurt her yet would I do her good,
Because ye extol her for perfect integrity,
But I had rather she were hanged by saint Antonie:
I would she were slain or banished the country,

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: What sayst thou.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: It is good to use such honest company.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: God save you my Lords, whose honours be excellent,
My Lord Gautier for you both hath sent,
And desireth you to haste to him with out delay,
for my Lady his wife is delivered this day,
Of a beautiful Child amiable to behold.

sp.speaker: Sobriete
sp.l: o happy day, o tidings sweet, our joys can scarce be told.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: Incontinent we ready are, with thee from hence to wend.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: Lead you the way right worthy Lords, on you I will attend.

sp.speaker: Pollitcke
sp.l: Fare ye well gentle gentle men, God be your speed,
Brought a Bed all ready, they have plied the box in deed,
I dare say it is some pretty mop-headed twig,
it is marvel she brought not a litter, for her belly was big:
Well let this pass, now this gear to cotton doth begin,
Let them laugh in the end that the victory doth win:
Since my former device, is thrust to exemption,
And that I cannot prevail with rancour and contention:
I will frequent through policy, another mean,
Wherewith I will molest and destroy her clean,
I will try her patience, another kind of way:
Let me see even so, it shall be I swear by this day,
Peace conceal thy purpose as yet Politic persuasion:
Till such time as thou see farther occasion,
Not a word more my Lord Marquis entereth the place,
now mayst thou contrive thy drift within short space.

body.stage: Enter Marques Singing to the tune of the latter Almain.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: I live in joyful jollity,
With my true love and Lady dear :
to me she giveth loyalty,
for Virtuous acts she hath no pear:
so true, so just, in word and deed,
I may her trust, in time of need:
her gentle heart through Wisdoms art,
so courteously doth play her part:
that needs I must express her praise,
Till direful death cut short my days.
Ye Heavens and powers divine, which did predestinate,
to me your creature framed of slime, such hap and lucky Fate:
As tendeth still to urge me forth, your praise to elevate,
Most happy be the time that I elected such a mate:
Whose loving heart excelleth far, Salutias Noble Dames,
her Godly heart is clean bereft of vain and wanton games:
A Dido for her Chastity, Penellope for truth,
A Thisbe for her ardent love, and Pyramus ensueth:
Cassandra she for patience, full aptly may be named,
Among the rout of chaste Dames, my Matron may be famed:
Whose vertues far abound, and sandy shores excel,
From Courtly Dames for counsel grave, my spouse doth bear the bell.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: God ye good-even my Lord with all my heart,
If your wife be so virtuous as now ye import,
Surely, surely she is worthy commendation,
she may be made a saint for her good conversation:
But hark my Lord nay now hearken in your ear,
Try her that way and by mine honesty I swear,
You shall see her decline from Virtues so rife,
And alter topsy turvy her saintish life:
her patience quickly shall changed be,
I warrant your honour will say it is not she.

sp.speaker: Gauter
sp.l: As sure as God doth live, and sit in heaven above ,
so sure will I in every point, this thy device approve:
therefore call in with speed, my servant Diligence,
that of this act, we may give him intelligence.

sp.speaker: Politick.
sp.l: Your will shall be performed without delay,
Hoaw Messenger, this place appropriate.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: who calleth for me, I am here by this day,
What is thy will? thy pleasure intimate.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Haste thee incontinent to my Lords presence,

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: that to do I am in a readiness.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: See that his person thou honour and reverence,
Dispatch whoreson Dreamer, go forward with speediness.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: Soft fire the common Proverb saith, sweet Malt doth make.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: The matter requireth haste, hence thy passage take.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: God save your honour and grant you his grace.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Messenger thou art heartily welcome to this place,
I have secret things to thee to inculcate,
give diligent ear, mark what I ostentate:
Thou knowest Grissill my Lady and wife,
With whom in love and fear I have lead my life:
Farther thou knowest my Daughter, which she doth nourish,
And with the Milk of her breasts foster and cherish,
I will that thou make semblant, at my commandment,
With thy sword in sunder, to divide that Innocent,
Yet shalt thou not hurt it, but to Bullin Lagras it convey,
to the Countess of Pango my sister, without let or staye,
who will nourish it and give it sustentation:
And bring her up in Godly and honest conversation.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: to this message you must take good regard,
Be well assured, thou shalt not lose thy reward.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: All that to me in charge, you now committed have,
shall be performed in all the haste, else God my soul ne save.

sp.speaker: Gautier
sp.l: If thou to any wight that lives, these Novels shown disclose.

sp.speaker: Pollitcke
sp.l: Gefferye Grimston at midnight,
Shall pluck thy bowels through thy Nose.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: My favourable love thyself for aye, shalt surely lose.

sp.speaker: Pollitcke
sp.l: for thy behaviour whoreson elf, thine ears shalt surely lose.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: God let me never live on earth, his vengeance heap my woe,
If I to any living wight this secret charge do shoe:
And as for this committed act, with all convenient speed,
These hands shall straight prepare, to execute the deed:
With violence the babe to pull from arms my heart is pressed,
Thus then the mothers heart with care and grief shall be distressed,
for I will fain that bloody sword, shall sunder and divide,
And scorch the Infants tender corps, with wounds both large and wide.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Peace not a word but gossip for twenty pound,
Your Spouse with her Nurse and Child, Enter into place,
You must counterfeit that Dolour may amply abound:
Let trickling tears be now distilled apace.

sp.speaker: Gauter.
sp.l: Your counsel grave to imitate, most willingly I will,
I am decreed in every point, your hest for to fulfil:
to tears my joys I now divert, my looks shall meastfull be,
no kind of solace now shall seem , to bide or rest in me:
My vigour and my feature fair, salt tears with spots shall stain
And woeful plaints shall forth ostend, my plight and pensive pain.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Come on my Nurse how doth our Child, I prithee forth express.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: The Child no doubt her perfect health, hath such is Gods goodness.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: God bless the little one, and shield thee with his grace,
Eke grant thee health and long to run, on earth thy vital race,
My Lord and spoused mate, resideth here in place,
Him to salute as duty binds, I will proceed a pace.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: And I will to his presence go, perhaps to get some gain,
for silly Nurses with young Babes, do watch and take much pain,
Thy smiling looks will gratulate, and heap thy father's joy,
God grant thee grace and thee preserve, from Gulfs of grief's annoy.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: God speed my Lord most honourable,
Why are you pensive what grief doth you betide,
Be of good cheer shoe yourself comfortable,
Set sorrow and sadness my Lord clean aside.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Bones how now how standeth the case,
in faith Dame thy sorrows do haste them a pace.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: o my Lord behold your Daughter dear , how prettily she doth smile
her pretty looks your tristfulness, with ease may clean exile.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Away Nurse these words are all together vain,
They minish not but more and more augment my pain,
The cause of dolour is so great that grief doth still a bound,
no kind of joy to ease my woe, can none for me be found,
The heaviest hap that ever chanced, is now to me be fall,
Was never Lord so tossed with pain, nor pinched to the gall,
o cruel wights, that cause my care, o stony hearts of flint,
Can never tears nor doleful paints, cause rigour for to stint,
But that ye will proceed to work your cursed will,
above all griefs this grief surmounts, an Infants blood to spill.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: O shoe to me thy mated wife, the thing that causeth care,
And I to suage thy pensive mind will remedy prepare.

sp.speaker: Gauter
sp.l: Thou canst not add relief my dear, if I the thing repeat
It rather will torment thy mind with painful passions great
The cause is this? my nobles my weeded state disdain,
And either will that I poor wretch, an exile shall remain,
And lose my ruling state, my treasure and my store,
which luckless hap in gushing kind, with tears mine eyes deplore,
Or else that our sweet child, which from these loins issued,
with direful sword, should murdered be, which thing my heart hath rued
Now to avoid their wrathful ire, and favour win again,
I grant and yield that this our Chid with sword shall straight be slain

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: o Lord my God what words are these they fill my heart with woe,
Ah silly wretch, must thou thy Child thus ruefully forego,
Would God in poor estate poor Grissill had remained,
Then void of cause thy tender heart, with woe had not been pained,
Ye matrons mild deplore my case, take fountains to your eyes
o let your clamours penetrate, the haughty clouded skies,
My Child alas in Childhood now, subjected to the sword,
O ruthless hearts which her to kill do cruelly accord,
What heart would condescend, to reave thee of thy life,
who would consent to scorch thy flesh, with cruel cut of knife,
This chance with patience, I will sustain and bear,
God will revenge this bloody fact, in end I nothing fear
My Lord the Daughter is your own, with her attempt your will,
If it seem pleasant to thy heart , thy pleasure now fulfil,

sp.speaker: Gautier
sp.l: Then take with speed thy glittering sword, proceed and play thy part
End thou her race fulfil their minds, straight gorge her through the heart .

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: Aloof thou Dame give me the Child, away and get thee hence.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: Alas my Lord be merciful, commit not such offence,
Consider how that God, which rules the haughty skies,
Each little thought for to be hold, hath opened wide his eyes,
And how then can so great a fact, from him concealed be,
which doth the thoughts of every wight, discern and plainly see,
Can murder then from him be close, no no my Lord not so
there is a God which to revenge, this act will not be sloe,
Perpend attend and give regard, to that which he hath said ,
Thou shalt not kill, let this precept of thee be rightly weighed,
Now if thou condescend thy flesh with death for to torment,
Thou canst not scape Gods wrathful ire, and grievous punishment.

sp.speaker: Gauter.
sp.l: O Nurse leave off such talk, in vain thou spendest thy breath,
it is not I that yield my Child to stroke of grisly death,
But spitefully my commons now, are inly puffed with hate,
And go about to short my life, such is my hapless state,
for either I from dignity, shall straight exempted be,
And abject like be thrown from rule such hap is chanced to me
that in exile as banished I ever shall remain.
Or else in haste deliver them this youngling to be slain,
And rather then from native town, I Gautier will go ,
Not my sweet babe but only I, will life and breath forego,
therefore leave off thy tears, thy plaints can find no grace.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Tush foolish woman this is a heavy case,
Better were it for him to have the Child slain,
Than his own person should suffer such pain.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: Yet Noble Lord if nature seem in thee to have a place
Preserve thy Child from death, end not her vital race,
The Tiger that in Wilderness, doth feed and ay remain,
will to the utmost of her might, her young ones shield from pain
The ravenous ramping Lion will, her whelps from danger save
The savage Bear with shape deformed will close in secret cave,
And often lick and cherish them, according to her kind,
Till clad with hair, and ugly shape, she like herself them find,
Then since that beasts which reason want, their proper ones defend
Much more should man, which wisdom hath for his own flesh contend.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: Cease for I will share with sword, the Infants corpse by force,
Ne on thy plaints nor on his tears I mind to take remorse.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Body a God this a Dick for the nonce by the rood,
He will do it he, and he say the word,
I warrant you full soon the younglings heart blood,
He will search and pearce with his glittering sword,
Tut I promise you this younker is one of them that God bade whoe,
for with him though I say it , there is but a word and a blow.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: I grant that beasts preserve by toil, their younglings from all woe
But if I should attempt the same, I should my life forgo,
What bodes it one though rule he bear, to take a sword in hand,
A thousand armed fighting men, to vanquish or with stand,
I then my life should lose, each wight my blood would spill,
Yet my death could not quench their thirst, but they would have there will
And then should Child and Father both, be slain on bloody sword,
Yet first that she be slain, my senses all accord.

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.l: Alas my Lady and Mistress must have a heavy heart,
to see her Child subject to such painful smart.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: o do not so but condescend, and grant my poor request,
And suffer not with violence, thy babe to be distressed,
give me the Child I pray, and save her from these foe,
for I will feed and nourish her, and take her as mine own
These breasts shall bring her up these hands shall find her food,
I will not cease but careful be to fend her guiltless blood,
Thus doing thou shalt stop the mouths, that would the babe devour
Thus doing she shall be preserved, her foes shall have no power,
to hasten this untimely death, and direful heavy fate,
And they against that mightful Ioue, no crime shall perpetrate,
for I from hence will take my flight and hence be clean exiled,
This will I do o worthy Lord, for safeguard of thy Child,

sp.speaker: Gauter.
sp.l: Let be these words they more increase my pain.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Nay nay with out all doubts the Child shall be slain,
Dispatch her speedily cease all this prattling.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: to sunder her body I straight will take pain,
The safeguard of her life hath caused this long tattling.

body.stage: Make as you would kill it.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Nay stay thy hand good friend, convey her out of place,
for nature will not let me see, her slain before my face,
But I shall yield up breath, and vital life soon end,
therefore from out our sights I pray, thee hastily do wend.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: All shall be done right sovereign Lord, as now you have me willed
I will not cease till rigorously, her blood with sword be spilled.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: Nay I will follow perhaps my mournful petition,
May cause him to leave his sinful intention.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Bones how like you this gear, the Nurse is gone after,
I cannot blame you if ye mourn for your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: o God my God what rigour now, have subjects against us used
Alas my woe increaseth much, how is my Lord abused,
Nay rather how doth Nature urge, me meastfully to wail,
to see how cruel destiny, against me doth prevail,
My Daughter reft from tender Paps, alas my woeful pain,
And causelessly by Tyrants fierce, with bloody sword thus slain,
Fare well sweet Child thy Mother now, shall see thy face no more,
Help spoused Dames help Grissill now, her fate with tears to implore
Gush forth your Briny streams let trickling tears abound
The earth and Firmament above, fill with your mournful sound
My Child alas in swaddling clouts, bereft and slain with sword.
Lord help, Lord aid, my woeful plight on me take some remorse,
Albeit such direful hap have chanced, grant patience to my pain
that I may seem this cross of thine, with joy for to sustain,
How now my loving Lord revive your heavy mind,
Come go with me to solace you, some joy shall be assigned.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: Beloved mate, whose wifely troth the sandy Seas excel,
I grant to execute such things as you shall forth retell.

sp.speaker: Pollitick
sp.l: Body a God what woman here could take the matter so patient
But rather pourforth tears her dolour to complain,
Yet she seemeth with this fact to be well content,
Though that her Child be murthered and slain.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Come on my mate let us from hence to pastimes sport now wend,

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: to go with you assuredly, my love I do intend .

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Ah sirrah are you all gone.
Is Politic Persuasion left here alone,
Well then where art thou whoreson awake or asleep ,
I think thy wits be gone goslings to keep,
Whop quoth I to my sheep, and had never a one,
Body and here is an empty head, for all the wit is gone,
Let me see, even so now lo, I have that I sought,
How like you my policies how wisely have I wrought,
Nay rather how like you her constancy and patience,
Truly that is wonderful strong in this inconvenience,
But as I have begun so will I afflict her still,
I am kin to a woman in all points I will have my will,
Fare ye well no remedy I must depart,
Fare well God be with you my Pigs nigh with all my heart ,
If you had Grissills patience and conditions excellent,
You and I would make a match to marry incontinent.

sp.speaker: Countes,
sp.l: Of Pango I the Countess am, my praise doth splendish bright,
Be loved I am for justice cause, of every faithful wight,
But one thing, heaps on heaps, our grief and doleful pain
And gives us cause in gushing kind, with tears to wail and plain
How spitefully hath death dealt now, with me most woeful wretch,
What meant you destinies so dire, your hands thus forth to stretch
And merciless to give such doom, as works a Ladies woe,
Forcing me my faithful mate, so soon for to forego,
Why rather reft ye not, my file by force in twain,
Your hateful ire with rigour mixed, to mourn doth me constrain

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.l: Comfort yourself my Lady dear, let sorrows now decrease
It is long time since that he died therefore your tears do cease
Can tears give life, or him restore to former life again,
no, why then do you most meastfully for him your mate complain
I judge that God displeased be, with this your heavy moan,
His race was run leave off your plaints for God will have his own

sp.speaker: Countis Pango
sp.l: My heavy mind you comfort much, but nature shoes her kind,
for she hath wellsprings to mine eyes, to mourn his death assigned,
His love his faith so fully shown, to me his spoused mate,
Doth give me cause to pour out plaints, to shoe my hapless fate,
But who is that that now to us hasteth thus a pace.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: A messenger my Lady fair, this is the certain case.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: God save and preserve you my Lady amiable,
And lengthen your life with prosperous increase,
Your brother Gautier my Lord most honourable,
Doth wish your health with quiet rest and peace,
Whose love to the world shall never cease,
He hath sent you here his Daughter young to cherish,
which he with Diligence doth trust you will nourish,
And to try the patience of his Lady and wife,
This action doubtless was attempted,
for she thinketh that the sword hath reft the babe of life,
Now therefore since my Lord this trial hath frequented,
He desireth your honour, as love tryst you hath ever been ostended
to conceal and keep secret this his intent,
And let it not be known but that it hath felt deaths dent.

sp.speaker: Countis
sp.l: Greet well my Lord and brother dear, I will perform his mind
to utmost of my might this shall, be done he hath assigned,
Welcome to me thou pretty one, thine aunt doth thee embrace,
My heart revives and skips for joy, to see thy pretty face,
Greet thou in my behalf my brothers noble wife,
Whose vertues blown a broad by Fame, appear in her most rife.

sp.speaker: Mesinger
sp.l: All shall be done as you do will, the Lord do you defend,
for to Salucia now I purpose straight to wend.

sp.speaker: Countis
sp.l: Fare well thou messenger, God in thy travel shield thee.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: And to his safeguard noble Dame, thy servant aye doth yield thee .

sp.speaker: Countis
sp.l: o lily Babe whose feature fair surmounts the ruddy rose
in shaping every limb of thee Nature did forth disclose,
her cunning skill for every wight that hath thy vigour seen,
May say and swear a fairer piece hath never framed been,
Come now receive this Child behold her seemly face,
her smiling cheer doth comfort me, God pour on her his grace.

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.l: o God thou God of mightful power, thou rock on who is staid,
My confidence and all my trust, my buckler and my aid,
What living wight hath seen, a fairer female Child,
her lively looks and shape so clear, hath dolour clean exiled.

sp.speaker: Countes,
sp.l: Come on to give it food let us depart this place.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I will attend on your honour by Gods grace.

sp.speaker: Pollitick
sp.l: Ah sirrah yonder is posting to every place,
Some run one way and some run another,
And I am sent also this is a plain case,
But by my hollidame I wot not whether,
even so now lo study and call to mind,
And see if the occasion thou canst find,
so lo now I have it I swear by Saint Richard,
The Marquis is in travel God be her speed,
And I am sent for mother Apleyarde,
who is a Midwife, a Midwife in dead,
Such matters you know should not be slacked,
Perchance if I tarry my flesh may be hacked.
Whoop who the Devil dwells here can any man tell,
Art thou a Maid or a widow that tendeth this house,
I think thou be sister to the vicar of Hell,
by my worship if I enter thou shalt bear me a souse.

sp.speaker: Midwife
sp.l: What pratest thou thou foolish knave canst thou tell.

sp.speaker: Politick
sp.l: Bones I promise you I have got a livery coat,
there is never a yard buts worth a flat groat,
Come on sirrah we will part stakes and that by and by,
for I knave can thou knave hastily espy.

sp.speaker: Midwife
sp.l: What lack you sirrah tell me with speed.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: I am sent for you Mistress Midwife in dead,
My Lady Marquis desireth you to come to her presence,
for of your aid she standeth in great need.

sp.speaker: Midwife
sp.l: I will go with you with all diligence,
for that Ladies vertues do fare exceed.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Come on I beseech you for we will go together,
The clouds be clear God send us fair weather.

sp.speaker: Midwife
sp.l: God in this enterprise be our staff and staye,
And send us in our business a most happy day,

sp.speaker: Gauter
sp.l: o Lord so my heart with pensiveness is afflicted,
to see how my Ladies, sorrows increase,
All solace and joy from her is rejected,
Of Child birth her pangs as yet do not cease
so that to see her tossed in such stormy woe,
My heart is perplexed all joy I forgo,
Well as one pensive, devoid of consolation,
I will rest me here some tidings to hear,
I descry one of my servants which with festination.
Unto my presence doth approach and draw near,
Welcome my friend what news hast thou brought.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: Such honourable Lord as to joy may elevate your thought,
My Lady of a beautiful man Child is delivered.

sp.speaker: Gautier.
sp.l: These tidings be joyful and sorrows have bereaved,
Take this reward thy pain to recompense,
to visit my spouse I will do my diligence,
which thus long hath suffered sorrowful smart,
But the little Babe will much revive her heart.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: My Lord hath given me a liberal reward,
His honour is now a very joyful man,
to us his servants he giveth such regard,
that we be bent to please him as we can,
The hole household are very joyful now,
Because our Lady mistress is delivered of a man Child,
And so is the hole country I may say to you
All tristful sorrow from them is exiled.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Cheer quoth you? marry cheer in black Bowls,
Quaffing, and carousing, for all christen souls,
A Christening quoth you marry there was a notable feast,
Five and forty hogsheads of wine spent at the least,
Fifty dozen Capons, and three times as many Swans,
Lafe, there was old sport to see the Skulls lick the Pans,
But a murrain of it it was my chance the feast to leese,
But I crammed my belly full of Cake bread and Cheese,
Stuffed like a Pudding bag full up to the throat,
See how fast the Buttons fly out of my Coat,
Feed yea faith I spared not, no I lustily feed
Eat my meat I can thank God, with him that Bears a head,
And as for carousing I think I did my part,
Seventeen gowns for my share, six pottles and a quart,
Thus judge my friends whether I have fed well or no,
I eat and drink merely where ever I do go,
But I must hence for the Marquis for me doth look,
Nay it is as I tell you, by the cross of this book:
Fare ye well and adieu I must hence a space,
But after a while you shall see this gentleman's face.
Go out.

body.stage: Enter the Nurse,bearing the childe in hir Armes.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: A joy to see how prettily, this Infant young can smile:
The sight of this the parents care and woe,
From hidden breast doth certainly exile,
This to be certain true the Gods do know,
And I poor Nurse am not a little glade,
to dandle this sweet soul my heart is fain,
I wish for it of Gods long life may be had,
that in Salucia joyful joy may remain,
to singe and to dance it, I mind to take pain,
I careful and diligent for it will abide ,
to rise early and sleep late I will not disdain,
to cherish and love it, it doth me betide.
Lullaby baby, lullaby baby.
Thy Nurse will tend thee, as duly as may be.
Be still my sweet sweeting, no longer do cry,
Sing lullaby baby, lullaby baby:
Let dolours be fleeting I fancy thee I,
to rock and to lull thee, I will not delay me .
Lullaby baby etcetera.
What creature now living, would hasten thy woe,
Singe lullaby, lullaby, lullaby baby:
See for thy reliving, the time I bestow,
to dance, and to prance thee, as prettily as may be.
lullaby baby etcetera.
The Gods be thy shield, and comfort in need,
Sing lullaby, lullaby , lullaby baby:
They give thee good Fortune, and well for to speed,
And this to desire, I will not delay me.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: Gog's heart and his heel, where is the brat,
Dispatch it quickly, nay I am flat:
I must and I will, dispatch it by saint Tan,
And why not, who should let me , no man:
Good fortune, the Nurse and the brat I espy,
With out peradventure, I will make as the child should die.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: Sweet babe be still, and take thy quiet rest,
Thy Nurse still to lull thee, doth give her consent:
to rock thee asleep , I mind to do my best,
Hush little baby, no longer do lament.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: Hush I will hush it, of this be thou bold,
Thou shalt of thy charge be now set free:
