And think not but truth to thee I have told,
The blood of the Infant, effused shall be,
My Lord hath given such commandment to me:
And therefore, see thou render it me without delay.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: to shield the poor Infant, I will do what I may ,
Although the one be slain, yet this shall not die.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: From thee force perforce, I will have it I,
too weak thou art found, with me for to strive.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: Yet will I assay, the victory to achieve,
Though inferior I seem to thee, in fortitude and strength,
Yet by words and plaints, I may prevail at length:
And therefore without delaying attend unto me,
give heed to my tears, let my words pondered be:
to slay this young Infant is contrary to reason,
Thy rage and fury vouch thou, with pity to season:
who would commit murther, or slay an Innocent
At any man's charge, and transgress Gods commandment,
Though favour of my Lord thou fortune to find,
Yet the righteous Judge above, hath thee vengeance assigned:
I wish thee therefore dilligently my words to scan,
And know it is better to please God, then than any mortal man.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: What tellest thou me that, I know it well enough I,
But if I kill it not I myself shall die,
therefore better to slay, than with the sword to be slain:
give me the brat therefore, thy plaints are spent in Vain.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: Alas yet hear me, one word let me speak,
seem not to kill it, neither so thy fury wreak,
that thereby you purchase then death and damnation,
But hark I will work I, for the childes preservation:
I will nourish it I and bring it up as mine own,
And that it liveth to my Lord need not be known:
Thus shalt thou please God, and the Marquis I say,
Yield to my desire I do thee heartily pray:

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: no? all this is vain, thy words are but waste ,
I will take the child and murther it in haste.
Go out.

sp.speaker: Nurs
sp.l: O cruel father, O most intolerable case,
in the breast of this Marquis Nature hath no place,
neither canst thou before God, thyself excuse
that seemest such tyranny to thy flesh to use,
to murther thy children, enlargeth my care:
to persevere in sin thyself thou dost prepare,
But woe to thee woe, whom the beasts do excel,
that in the deserts continually do dwell:
The Lioness her whelps, doth earnestly tender,
The Bear to her young ones in love is not slender,
But thou to thy own flesh art father unkind,
to cry out against thee, poor Nurse I do mind.
The venomous Serpent the Crocodile most dire,
to bring up her young hath careful desire:
The merciless Tiger devoid of all favour,
to nourish her younglings doth earnestly labour,
But thou (alas) disdainest thy flesh for to feed,
Thou rather delightest to make their hearts bleed.
Two Children to death, thou now hast condemned:
But know that the Lord, thou hast greatly offended,
I mourn thee poor Grissill thy hap I lament,
But thou in this case art marvelous patient:
to court I will haste me, to comfort thee all that may be ,
But to cry out on the Marquis I will not delay me .

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Ah sirrah I have touched her I trow,
Politic Persuasion hath given Grissell a blow,
a blow quoth you? such a one as sorrow might increase ,
But by his Bones her mourning doth cease,
Yet she thinketh her little son is slain,
But my policies deceive her this is plain,
for it is sent to Bullin Lagras the truth is so,
to the Marquis sister, the Countess of Pangoe
who will nourish it, as it is well known ,
As she doth his Daughter, which is kept as his own ,
But since that neither of these attempts her patience can move,
I am minded against her a new assault to prove,
which shall exempt her from the top of fortunate prosperity,
And plunge her deep in the floods of adversity,
Behold yonder they enter both together ,
Surely I mind to give her , her welcome hither ,
God save your honours may I be bold with you my Lord to have a word or twain
Truly for your profit I would speak with you fain.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Say what you please I am ready thee to hear.

sp.speaker: Perswa
sp.l: Then I beseech you come apart for it is secret gear.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: With all my heart hear thee I will.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: And in faith I will seek to pleasure you still,
Hark it is even so, you shall well espy,
Hark again, this is the mean her patience to try.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: Lord this device I will straight put in ure,

sp.speaker: Politick.
sp.l: I warrant you her damage it shall procure,
Now shall ye see my purpose fadge,
I trow we shall have some pastime anon mother madge.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Madam my dear and spoused mate, attend and give good head,
to such words as from me thy Lord, at this time shall proceed,
Thou seest our painful plight, our grief full well is shown,
our children's loss to each of us, apparently is known:
Yet cannot death of Infants dear, appease the bloody mind,
Of nobles all, nor staunch the rage of commons most unkind,
But now their rage reverted is, to quite me with disdain,
They seek God knows to banish me, from Empery and Reign,
And thou art root of all my grief, my anguish and my care.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Am I the spring that vexeth thee, my loving Lord declare.
Hath wifely troth aye failed thee, hath duty been neglect,
Doth any wight that liveth now , of these things me suspect,
But if I be the cause, that bereaves thee of thy joy:
If I be she o noble Lord, that worketh thine annoy,
As my sweet Babes at Tyrants hest, have died on bloody knife,
to assuage their rage, and win thee grace: spare not thy faithful wife
Let thousand gashes scorch this flesh, let them their rage display,
Let thousand wounds by stroke of knives, take Grissills life away

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Body of me see her gentle disposed mind,
how many such wives may a man find:
Which seeing their husbands oppressed with woe,
Would willingly offer their lives to forgo,
to mitigate the husbands pain, or ease his grief:
Not one I conjecture I am so horde of belief.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: My loving mate, thy life untouched, in safeguard shall remain,
Thy blood shall not effused be, but needs I must be plain,
And eke express the hole effect, why they frequent this spite
their muttering voice concealed long , is shown in open sight,
They envy my estate, so fell doth Fortune frown,
Thou only art the blemisher, of honour and renown,
Thy poor degree, impoverisheth, my worthiness and fame,
Thy poverty eclipseth much, my dignity and name,
therefore as poor thou wert, so poor thou shalt abide,
And to thy needy father wend, these Robes set clean aside,
for I will wed another wife, which shall mine name advance,
to top of Fortune's haughty while my fame she shall enhance
her noble stock and years shall equal be to mine,
She shall proceed and Issue from some princely famous line,
But as thou didst in naked plight from thy poor parent wend,
so barely knacked to him again I purpose thee to send,
Thus shall my nobles joy, their hate, full soon shall cease,
And I their Lord successively, shall spend my days in peace.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Bones quod joiner who made God all mighty,
These news will vex and grieve her spitefully,
to be banished so suddenly from her husbands side,
And he to marry another, clocking Mistress Bride
Would move the patience of a good many wives,
I dare say they had rather be rid of their lives.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Most humble here my sovereign Lord, thy listening ears prepare
Attentively give good regard, to that I shall declare,
When I in poor estate did live, there with I was content,
I praised my God, and bare the cross, that he to me had sent
like case when that to this estate, your mate ye did elect
My lo degree this choice of thine, unfit did suspect,
I thought that twixt my vacant plight, and needful indigence,
Thy rich estate, and Lordly rule, deserving reverence,
Might no comparison be made, and therefore as unmeet,
I deemed myself within thy roof to place or set my feet,
Yet did thine honour noble Lord, elect me for thy mate,
The greater ruth the more my pain, and most unhappy Fate
First both my babes dismembered are, the sword their flesh hath torn
Next causelessly to cruciate me, new troubles they adorn,
which patiently I woeful wife, of women all forlorn,
will bide and bear laughing my foe, fond Fortune all to scorn,
But if this banishment, and absence of thy wife,
And twixt the Lordly sort and thee, end this conceived strife,
I grant with willing mind, from hence to take my passage,
And rest me as I did tofore, within my fathers cottage.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: o heart now reave and rend, now break thou clean in sunder
The heavens above and lumining stars, at this attempt may wonder
All living wights that hear this fact will me reward with shame
no condign praise, but ill report, shall thunder forth my Fame,
Shall I forgo my wedded wife, whose wifely troth is such,
that aye to do her husband good, her life thinketh not much,
What though from simple stock, her nature be derived,
her vertues yield such equal doom, that honours she achieved,
And shall I then reject, as abject from my sight,
My Lady dear, whose vertues all, my senses much delight,
no no not so, pluck back thy feet, such acts exile thy thought,
Let no such sin against thy love in any wise be wrought.

sp.speaker: Politick.
sp.l: What body a me, my Lord pluck up your heart,
Be frolic and joyful set sorrows apart,
Are you not ashamed to blubber and weep,
It is time now to play the man, and not a simple sheep,
Proceed forward faint not, your purpose prosecute,
Be not reputed a coward, the fact execute,
Let your countenance be stern, like a gentleman look big,
else for this drift I will not give a fig.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: Following the motions of Politic Persuasion,
Against her stoutly I will make invasion.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Then do you well I swear by Saint tan,
I swear by mine honour ye shall be deemed a man.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Atwight not me with fortune Dame, cease soon I do thee pray,
I must and will defend myself lest happily I decay,
Come off despoil thyself , cast off thy rich array,
From princely state, to fathers house, all naked take thy way.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Thy will forth with shall straight be done, obedient I will be,
to do the things my worthy Lord that you commanded me.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Whope hoyda now Saint, Gillian bless ye,
in faith pretty sweeting these tidings deceases ye.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Alas Madam it grieveth me this day to see.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Be not sorrowful at all, for this much pleaseth me,
for by my departure my Lord shall live in rest,
His afflicted heart with careful thoughts oppressed,
Shall find a salve of safeguard, to cure his pain,
which doubtless shall make poor Grissill fain,
therefore dear Damsel thy lamentation cease,
Since that my absence shall joys innumerable increase,
The commons rage to mildness shall be diverted,
The nobility shall shun stubbornness, and become gentle hearted,
These consuming Agonies which so much torment the mind,
Of my singular suffering, shall be sure redress to find.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Bones of a Tabor with this fact she is pleased,
She careth not so her Lords pains be eased,
I have not seen her like, her patience doth exceed,
I say no more but God send us good speed,
How many such be living at this day,
Not one I conjecture for Grissils decay,
Thereby a number living that Grissills have to name,
But yet very shrewish by natural disposition,
their manners assuredly far differ from the same,
Let the married sort here of make definition,
for the woman oft times to choler the good man will provoke,
Be well assured they must bear the greatest stroke.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Take here these Robes and ornaments costly,
Take here these things and jewels sumptuous,
Take here the Ringe where with we joined Matrimony,
which day was solemnised and to all men joyous,
Bestow them where it shall please thee, my Lord most bounteous
for all that ever I received of thee, I yield thee again,
Being well contented in my former state to remain,
Yet most worthy Lord, I do the humbly desire,
One simple boon grant me for a recompense,
The thing is of small value that I shall require,
which I beg on my knees with honour and reverence.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: speak Grissill if thy Boon be simple I grant thy request
Arise incontinent let it be forth expressed.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: I thank your honour for your benevolence,
Beseeching God to shield thee from all in convenience,
on me some time thy wife take remorse,
Extend not against me the fulness of rigours force,
But plant pity in thy breast be somewhat more favourable,
Consider it were great ignomy to thy estate honourable,
to send me away naked to my fathers cottage,
And to me wretched wight ten times more damage,
for all creatures shall be hold the secrete corps of mine,
which sometimes were most amorous and pleasant to thy eyen,
Grant therefore this request to me woeful wight,
Let pity subdue and vanquish rancorous spite,
A simple Smock to hide and cover my nakedness,
Be it never so simple I beseech your goodness,
which I crave, to recompense my virginity,
The which I brought but carry not away with me,
Let not me be made a laughing stock I pray thee ,
But grant my request and take pity on me.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: I grant thy desire a Smock thou shalt have,
And be conveyed to thy father like case.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Truly no other thing of thee I will crave,
I praise God that in thy sight I have found grace,
And since this as my dowry in age is ordained,
Most lovingly this scourge shall be entertained.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: Come Grissill without longer delay,
Thou shalt to thy father this present day.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Most willingly on your Lordship I will attend,
Being desirous to him for to wend.

sp.speaker: Politicke
sp.l: Ah sirrah this gear is trimly handled by Saint. tan,
how say you hath not Policy now played the man,
she shall home to her father she, this is trim:
But her sudden fall will trouble the heart of him,
Fare ye well all, I will be packing,
Tush there wants a man, where Policy is lacking.

sp.speaker: Rumor
sp.l: What thing so ever is attempted,
Or through the world frequented,
From Rumour cannot concealed be ,
for I spread it through the whole country,
And now have I occasion my trump to blow,
And expressly publish poor Grissills woe,
From the top of honour, the Marquis will her exile,
for Fortune is fickle, although she do smile,
her changes unstable, full of mutability,
her wheel is full gliding, and of no certainty,
her fresh visage, full soon changeth cheer,
As now by Lady Grissill doth plainly appear,
for she is now thrown, from the top of prosperity,
And with old Iannickle, must suffer painful poverty,
which fact swiftly through Salutia I will blow,
that all living creatures his cruelty may know .

sp.speaker: Vulgus
sp.l: What Tumult through out Salutia is spread,
A wonderful Rumour among the commons is risen of late,
A sudden report through out the town is fled:
which forceth us all, to bewail Grissills state,
Against her causeless is by him kindled much debate,
for he will exile from him, this Lady of excellence:
And constrain her now to live in needful indigence,
which thing to think on, so pinch these our hearts,
that for her sake we are fain tears to distill,
she often relived our penury and smarts,
And therefore for her now , of force lament I will:
It is even so this chance happeneth most ill,
Yonder she entereth alas and well away,
our hearts are made sorrowful to see this day.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: o Lady we mourn and shed tears, this day to behold.

sp.speaker: Sobriete
sp.l: our minds are meastfull, piteous plaints we unfold.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Comfort yourselves my Lords, set heaviness apart,
for Patience to suffer this, hath armed my heart :
This Cross is not contemned, but willingly embraced,
on God my trust, and confidence is placed,
therefore mourn no more, be neither sorrowful nor sad:
But I rejoice in God, my heart is full glad.

sp.speaker: Vulgus
sp.l: o Grissill Grissill our hearts are full of heaviness,
Would God we had wherewith, to cover thy nakedness:
Then should we add remedy to this thy grief,
Thou surely at our hands, shouldst find some relief:
But woe be to this Marquis, which hath heaped thy pain,
on his cruelty, we have just cause to complain:
Woe be to this Marquis, ye cursed be his days
And this shall be my prayer, now and always.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: Low Madam, we approach your fathers house at this season.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Friends in place I have been very geason,
But now my fathers presence I shall continually behold,
Whose company to me, is more dearer than Gold.

sp.speaker: Ianickle
sp.l: What clamorous noise is this, that I hear,
that all be not well, I greatly fear,
(Alas) my Daughter Grissill all naked I see,
which sight to discern, much grieveth me,
Well I will haste to cloth her, with all convenient speed,
With this ragged coat, which I have kept xii. years in deed.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: Behold father Iannickle, my Lord hath sent you a present.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie.
sp.l: for as she came naked, so naked he hath her sent.

sp.speaker: Ianickle
sp.l: thank my Lord of his gentleness and courtesy,
Tell his honour my Daughter, is right welcome to me.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: we are but the messengers, of his honourable mind,
And now that our functions is ended,
we commit thee to God, o Grissill most kind:
to go homeward, we are intended.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: God in your going be your aid and guide,
Commend me to your Lord with humble salutation,
Tell him I will pray for him day time and tide,
I beseech God be his preservation.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie
sp.l: Grissill all that you have said shall performed be,
Father Iannickle our message is ended
And God be with ye.

sp.speaker: Ianickle
sp.l: Fare ye well, God be your defender,
for your Lords courtesy, thanks to you I render.
o my child, and dearly beloved,
to pour forth foison of tears, for thee I am moved:
o heart break in pieces, now sorrow is revived,
to see thee of dignity thus clean deprived:
Receive thine own Coat, and cover thy nakedness,
which I have kept as treasure is, with diligentness:
ever doubting that this Marquis would displeased be,
With thy low estate, and indigent poverty,
What father could choose, but on Fortune complain,
which such hard Fate for thee doth ordain,
o froward Fortune, all together deceivable,
Full of Garish flattery, all together variable:
The changes of thy haughty wheel, to Luna I may compare,
who so trusteth thee hath often cause of care:
From prosperity to adversity the simple thou dost throe,
Fie on thee Fortune, which art cause of my woe.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: o father be joyful and praise God for my fall,
for he that gave prosperity, can send adversity:
And at his prescript pleasure he can assuage the thrall,
Of such as be afflicted with needful poverty,
Embrace Patience, let go rash temerity:
Blame not Fortune for my overthrow,
It was the will of God, that it should be so:
And what creature living, can withstand his providence,
This Cross is to try us, as he doth his elect,
therefore good father, arm yourself with Patience:
Let not murmuration your heart infect,
But bless me Iehoua which his doth direct,
Then will he protect us, from danger and harm,
therefore with Patience, ourselves let us arm.

sp.speaker: Ianickel
sp.l: Daughter I praise God as duty doth me bind,
But yet this fall of thine will no part from my mind,
o how is my heart perplexed with woe,
Not one but God my anguish doth know.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Good father I beseech you set mourning aside,
Cast your care on God who for us will provide,
These hands shun idleness the Nurse of wickedness,
My Rock and Distaff, are instruments doubtless,
With which as I have in times past, so now in dead,
will I labour and toil our bodies to feed.

sp.speaker: Pacience
sp.l: I represent a virtue called Patience,
Very meet and needful for such as suffer affliction,
I comfort the mind tossed with inconvenience,
And instruct them humbly to suffer punission,
I teach them patiently to endure correction,
so that in trouble I am a safe preservation,
Meet for all those that bide vexation.

sp.speaker: Constanci
sp.l: like case I Constancy, am of like excellence
I keep the mind, upright from the gulfs of despair,
A sufficient preservative am I, to the feebled conscience
I teach him on God to lay the yoke of all his care,
Constancy causeth him to truth to repair,
so that who so hath us, too much ease shall find,
for we are perfect props to the disquieted mind.

sp.speaker: Pacience
sp.l: I patience expulse tears lachrimable,
And add to the sorrowful comfortable relief.

sp.speaker: Constanci
sp.l: And I constancy, to the tristful am profitable,
I teach them amidst their trouble, to forget grief.

sp.speaker: Pacience
sp.l: to these two present, myself I injugate.

sp.speaker: Constanci
sp.l: With patience I constancy am always confederate,
And there with them, like case I will reside.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Father be joyful let your sorrows slide,
Behold these vertues which God hath us sent,
to embrace patience with me, good father be diligent,
This is a medicine for us very comfortable.

sp.speaker: Ianickel
sp.l: dear Daughter to your sayings I am agreeable,
Welcome patience a necessary instrument,
to them that in conscience do suffer torment.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Lay hold on Constancy, which from Despair will us shield.

sp.speaker: Ianakell
sp.l: to do as you do, in all things I yield.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: so, now if you please let us depart.

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: I grant to go hence with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Pacience
sp.l: And I Patience, on you will attend.

sp.speaker: Constanci
sp.l: in storms tribulous constancy shall you defend.

sp.speaker: Diligence
sp.l: From my Lord Marquis even now I am sent,
who even now is journeyed to Bullin Lagras,
to fetch whom his new spouse a Lady excellent,
As beautiful as ever the Greekish Hellin was,
Whom Paris the Troyean, hath won in fight,
And brought to Priams Court, by puissant might.
But at this season according to my Lords commandment,
which with humility I will bring to perfection,
As it becommeth every servant to be diligent,
so as I am charged, I will give Grissill here of intellection,
Hark, methinks I hear her voice delectable,
Surely to virtue, this Lady was tractable,
How God be here, who resteth in this place.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: My poor Father and I this is a plain case.

body.stage: Go once or twise about the Staige, let Grissill Singe some songe, and sit Spinninge.
A songe for Grissill when the Messinger commeth to hir.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: How greatly am I bound to praise
My God that sits in Throne,
which hath assuaged by providence,
My anguish and my moan.
These vertues which with me reside
all griefs have banished quit,
Patience do ease my heaviness
and pensive pained plight.
Eke Constancy from all annoy
doth Grissill daily shield,
so that I will be joyful still,
and praise to God aye yield.
which in this grievous doleful fall,
such mercy doth extend:
As from the gulfs, of fond Despair,
his creatures doth defend.
The surging Sea, so troublous,
which tossed me to and fro:
Whose watery waves had sunk me nigh,
in floods of deadly woe,
Allayed are, and I set free,
from peril and from pain:
The Lord above, of his mere love ,
no doubt hath made me fain.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: God save thee Grissill and shield thee from care,
My Lord Marquis, doth him to thee commend,
Desiring thee home to his place, to repair,
for to wed a new Lady, he doth purpose and intend ,
But the rule of his house, is assigned only to thee,
All the officers of his house, shall to thee obedient be ,
But above all things thou must make provision,
that his new Spouse may be lodged after the best wise:
The order of all things, must be assigned to thy discretion,
All things shall be done, as you do devise.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: With all my heart I will lay my Rock aside,
to pleasure his honour, in all that I can.

sp.speaker: Dilligenc
sp.l: Then in this place, let us no longer abide,
for I purpose to be your waiting man.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Come on my Lady dear, my Spouse and loving mate,
The gods be blessed which unto me , have given such lucky Fate,
As to enjoy so fair a wife, whose feature doth excel,
The Golden Nymphs, and Muses nine, which on Pernasso dwell:
These arms thy corps embrace, on thee my joy depends,
to pleasure thee my Lady dear, thy husbands mind attends.

sp.speaker: Daughtr
sp.l: And eke to thee as duty binds, loves fruits I will impart,
Thou only my beloved mate, enjoyest thy servants heart:
The fruits of friendly love, to thee shall still be shown,
My heart is thine, receive the same, and take it as thine own.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Possess thou mine while death divide, and shred my File in twain,
As long as life abides in corps, thine own I will remain:
Rejoice ye Nobles all, dear sister joyful be,
for now my joys increased are, my Nuptials you shall see,

sp.speaker: Countis
sp.l: O Brother mine gods give you joy, and lengthen long your lives,
Be present Himeneus thou, the vanquisher of strives:
Subdue the Furies fell, whose visages ugly black,
Prognosticate that joyful joys, shall come to ruinous wrack.

sp.speaker: Brother
sp.l: Amen and Ioue that rules, the earth and heaven above ,
The Planets seven and every thing, that orderly doth move,
Send such increase of friendliness, that discords fruits may cease,
And faithful love betwixt you twain, may more and more increase.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: I thank you both for your good wills, now let us haste away,
in pompous wise to solemnise, our happy spousal day.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Now that I have set all things in a readiness,
for the coming of my Lord, I purpose to attend,
Whose honour I will receive with willingness:
And the fruits of good will to him still ostend,
Patience is the Buckler wherewith I contend,
And Constancy in combat, stayeth me upright,
These so arm me, that I cannot be vanquished in fight:
Lo behold yonder they begin in presence to appear,
Certes his spouse is wonderful Amorous,
With him like case, cometh a young man wonderful fair,
I will salute them with loquie courteous:
God save you my Lord, and send you his peace,
Welcome fair Lady, God send thee prosperity,
God bless thee O my Lord, with Wisdoms increase,
God preserve you all, right worthy Nobility.
God grant you to spend your time in tranquillity:
God stream on thy famous assembly, the spirit of grace,
And grant you long, on earth to run your race.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: we thank thee Grissill for thy courteous salutation,
And re-greet thee again, with like gratulation,
But tell one thing, that I shall of thee require,
Show frankly thy mind, I do thee humbly desire:
How sayst thou? is not my spouse beautiful and fair ,
Bash not I pray thee, but boldly thy fancy declare.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: My Lord touching your inquisition,
Gladly ye shall hear poor Grissills definition:
her comely shape Nature hath framed aright,
Each lively limb appears, full shining in my sight,
her visage white, with redness mixed I deem,
Would move every creature, her beauty to esteem,
And to conclude, in my simple judgment,
there cannot in the world be a fairer, this is evident:
But hark my Lord, what I say to thee again,
Take heed thou prick her not, with the Needles of disdain:
As thou hast done the other, for she hath been brought up daintily,
And peradventure, cannot take the matter so patiently.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: o Grissill thy Virtues I must commend,
even thou only, deservest perpetual praise:
What tongue sufficiently, can thy laud ostend,
I have not seen thy like in all my days,
for faithful love, thou dost far exceed,
Dido,Penellope or any such in dead:
Thou only art my Spouse, and beloved mate,
Thee only I fancy, all other Spousals I hate:
And this Virgin which thou deemest, my Spouse shall be ,
Is thy Daughter and mine, this is the verity,
And this young man, which thou seest in sight,
Is thy son and mine, my love and Lady bright:
They were not slain, but Nourished tenderly,
With my sister, the Countess of Pango verily:
therefore be joyful, set sorrows aside,
Thou art my love, my Lady, and Bride:
And this which I have done, I promise thee I,
Was done for this cause, thy Patience to try.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: My Children, o most fortunate day,
Blessed be God, that kept you from decay:
Fall down.
Ah I thought the sword, had ended your race,
But now I praise God, I view your comely face.

sp.speaker: Daughtr
sp.l: Ah my sweet mother, did thou suffer such pain,
for me thy Child, great is thy Patience,
God grant I may kindly, reward thee again,
With the perfect fruits, of Childly obedience.

sp.speaker: Sonne
sp.l: Ah dear mother, in whose womb I was nourished,
And therein by divine essence, forty weeks cherished,
hast thou suffered for me, such anguishing tribulation,
God grant I may requite thee , with condign veneration.

sp.speaker: Countis
sp.l: o Sister great cause have you joyful to be.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: Ah it delighteth me much, my Children to see,
My joys so far exceed and be innumerable,
that no wight living, to shoe them is able,
I cannot utter my mind tears so abound,
Wherefore at this instant, let us depart this place.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: we are glad that Grissill such favour hath found.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie
sp.l: Truly these tidings, the commons will solace.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Come on Nobility, let us hence wend.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: on your honour willingly we will attend.

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: Much musing in mind, where my Grissill is thus long ,
My wavering mind is tossed, with thoughts to and fro,
I pray God this Marquis have done her no wrong,
Nor sought means further, to trouble me with grief and woe,
for then shall old Ianickle his life soon forego,
her damage is mine, her harm as mine I take,
Till such time as I see her, my sorrows cannot slake,
Good luck I trust, for the Marquis entereth this place,
I will haste to him with all festination,
And rest me behind him, a little space,
Peradventure I shall hear news, by his communication.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: What say you my Lords, doth not Grissill excel.

sp.speaker: Reason
sp.l: From all spoused Dames she beareth the Bell,
I have not seen her like since the time of my creation,
Worthily deserveth she, praise and laudation.

sp.speaker: Sobriete
sp.l: Grissill your spouse doth merit commendation,
her Fame is blown through every nation,
All creatures living may speak of her praise,
I never knew her like in all my life days.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: Then this one thing I pray you tell me,
Is it not convenient, that after me her Children reign,
And enjoy over Salutia rule and dignity,
Here in I desire you shoe your judgments plain.

sp.speaker: Reason.
sp.l: Right honourable Lord avoiding dangers, and doubts scrupulous
I frankly and freely, make protestation,
that her condition, being as they be most virtuous
Shall cause her Children to be had in estimation,
And God willing as our superiors, they shall rule this nation,
for since they be the fruits, which from your loins did proceed,
Of force they shall posses, your inheritance in dead.

sp.speaker: Sobrietie.
sp.l: And I plight my faith thereto, for performance of the same,
else God confound me with confusion and shame.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: I give you most humble thanks for your good will,
in that ye are bent to mine, after me allegeance to fulfil,
Come on I beseech ye and walk with me a little way.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.l: we are ready pressed, your honour to obey.

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: These comfortable tidings, comfort my aged heart ,
Be merry now Ianickel let all sorrows depart,
Blessed be God the giver of all consolation,
which hath stirred this Marquis on Grissill to take compassion.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: God speed good father, how is it with thee,
think not but thou art highly beloved of me,
o thy courtesy in my sight hath found grace,
Not as a stranger, but as my father I thee embrace,
Put off these garments for thee most unfit,
for thou shalt be honoured through out this City,
Cloth thyself with these Ornaments with out longer delay,
Help my Nobility, my father to array,
Shall not I love thee, and yield the veneration,
which to my spoused mate extendest compassion,
to harbour her in need you doubtless were diligent,
therefore to prefer thee to honour, I judge it convenient,
Within my roof thou shalt be placed,
Let joys a bound, and sorrows be defaced.

sp.speaker: Ianickell
sp.l: o honourable Lord, Ioue reward this kindness,
which to me poor Ianickle you presently ostend,
God increase thee with wisdom, I beseech his goodness,
And from all dangers thy person defend,
which the fullness of friendship dost friendly extend,
to me croked wight, and my Daughter thy wife,
I being half dead, you have revived my life.

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.l: O Father repeat not my unkindness I pray thee ,
which afflicted thy Child, with the scourge of adversity,
But learn now in thine old days joyful to be,
And posses with us Gods gift prosperity,
Come on to our Mansion, let us all together repair.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: to wait on your honour we diligent are.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Come on my dear Sister whose kindness to recompense,
Poor Grissell is unable, which keptest from inconvenience,
My Children, fostering them as thine own
God grant my good will to thee may be shown.

sp.speaker: Countis
sp.l: Sister that which I did, proceeded from my heart,
It sufficeth me that thanks to me ye do impart.

sp.speaker: Grissill
sp.l: else might I be counted of all creatures most unkind,
Verily your kindness, shall never out of my mind,
o my Children, your Mothers heart is made fain,
Where as with Cleopatra I had cause to complain,
Now reject I sorrow, and mourning cheer
And constrained am to joy, to see you living here.

sp.speaker: Daughtr
sp.l: o my beloved Mother, great was the tribulation,
which your Motherly heart for us did endure.

sp.speaker: Sonne
sp.l: But now our presence, ten times more consolation,
to you I hope shall daily procure.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Truth, but yet one thing doubtless increaseth my sorrow,
And will force me to shed tears, even and morrow,
o my dear Father thy absence I be wail,
to see thee suffer indigent grief, doth my heart assail
Would God with in our roof, thou mightest thy place in joy
Then doubtless were eased my grief and annoy,
Let me see o heart thy dolours abrogate,
Let joy abound thy former solace revocate,
Behold thy husband and thy Fathers aged face,
who both together friendly do enter this place,
His rags are changed to Silks I perfectly see,
Now know I assuredly my Lord doth favour me.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Come on good Father, rejoice and be merry,
With pensive state I judge you be weary,
Behold thy Daughter my Lady and wife,
With whom God willing, I will end this life,
Behold my two Children revive thyself again,
Embrace gladness, oblate thy former pain.

sp.speaker: Ianickle
sp.l: God be blessed, which from so great adversity,
Hath elevated us to great prosperity,
Ah sweet Children God bless you, and send you his grace,
My heart doth leap to behold your face,
Now have I seen that, which I long to see desired have,
Now doth my hoary head covet the grave,
Now doth death delay time and spare his dart,
And will not sunder, old Ianickells heart.

sp.speaker: Grissell
sp.l: Good father covet not death, your race is not run,
The destinies more longer, your thread have spun.

sp.speaker: Sonne
sp.l: o Grandfather praise God, and wish not your death.

sp.speaker: Daughtr
sp.l: Nay rather desire him, to lengthen your Breath.

sp.speaker: Marques
sp.l: Come on now let us to our place with joyfulness,

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: we all will attend on you with willingness.

sp.speaker: Postemus Actor
sp.l: Here to conclude right gentle audience,
At this season, we purpose and intend
Beseeching you all, with us to have patience,
for loath would we be, the simplest here to offend,
in our author's behalf to you we did commend,
This history, wherein we have been bold to shoe
What virtues in Grissell that Lady did floe:
Although rude our doings, and author's metre be,
Yet seem not us, nor him to deface,
we submit ourselves, unto your judgments we
And thus we knit up, with support of your grace.
Desiring your prayers with us in this case,
in which our Noble Queen Elesabeth, to you we commend,
Whom God in the Bowels of his mercy do defend,
Bless her O Father, and grant her Nestors days,
Shield her with the wings of his mercy and grace,
that as she hath begun to set forward thy praise,
so strength her Lord, to advance thine honour in every place,
Her foes and enemies utterly deface,
Whether they be foreign or civil, let their confusion be seen
Lord bliss thou our land, and preserve our Royal Queen.
The Lords of the Counsel, Lord Govern aright,
that they may be mindful of the common weal,
Shadow and defend them, with thy glorious sprite,
that unto thy truth they may bear love and zeal,
Unto them (O God) the sprite of knowledge reveal,
that sin may be extirpated and rooted out quite,
And we unto truth, and virtue, fix our delight.
